review.title: ABA+: Assumption-Based Argumentation with Preferences
review.abstract: We present ABA+, a new approach to handling preferences in a well known structured argumentation formalism, Assumption-Based Argumentation (ABA). In ABA+, preference information given over assumptions is incorporated directly into the attack relation, thus resulting in attack reversal. ABA+ conservatively extends ABA and exhibits various desirable features regarding relationship among argumentation semantics as well as preference handling. We also introduce Weak Contraposition, a principle concerning reasoning with rules and preferences that relaxes the standard principle of contraposition, while guaranteeing additional desirable features for ABA+.
histories: This is a preprint of a manuscript under review

sections.text: ar Xiv: 161 0.03 024v 1 [cs.A I] 1 0O ct2 016We introduce ABA +, a new approach to handling preferences in a well-known structured argumentation formalism, Assumption-Based Argumentation (ABA). In ABA +, preference information over assumptions is incorporated directly into the attack relationship, leading to a reversal of the attack. ABA + conservatively expands ABA and displays various desirable features in relation between argument semantics and preference handling. We also introduce Weak Contraposition, a principle that argues with rules and preferences that loosens the standard principle of comparison while guaranteeing additional desirable features for ABA +.

It has been shown that argumentation is a perspicuous abstraction method that covers several existing argumentation paradigms, in particular non-monotonous argumentation and logic programming. sections.heading: 7.5 Other Formalisms
sections.text: ASPIC − [22] proposed a simplified version of ASPIC +, called ASPIC −, with a variation of the ASPIC + attack relationship, called unrestricted rebound. In ASPIC − axioms and premises are omitted and instead presented as strict and defective rules. However, the new attack relationship is based on the idea that while (default) rebut in ASPIC + is allowed only on the conclusion of a defective rule, unrestricted rebound is allowed on the conclusion of each rule. An essential feature of ASPIC − is that it only works with the total preference of orders over vanquishable rules, and if a partial arrangement is used instead, as in ABA +, then extensions under different semantics need not postulate rationality [21] or prove other desirable properties, as mentioned in [22] by analyzing example 17.

metadata.abstractText: We present ABA, a new approach to handling preferences in a well known structured argumentation formalism, Assumption-Based Argumentation (ABA). In ABA, preference information given over assumptions is incorporated directly into the attack relation, thus resulting in attack reversal. ABA conservatively extends ABA and exhibits various desirable features regarding relationship among argumentation semantics as well as preference handling. We also introduce Weak Contraposition, a principle concerning reasoning with rules and preferences that relaxes the standard principle of contraposition, while guaranteeing additional desirable features for ABA.
